Comment: My favourite English Opening.
A standard response.
I used to move 2.g3 but employ the more cautious 2.Nc3 now.
Nf6 is more usual but this is not a bad move.
I could have moved Nf3 either.
Nf6 this time - still the most common response to 3.g3 per the GameKnot DB.
I've started so I might as well finish, although the Games BD prefers Nf3
The first departure from the orthodox response.  The Games DB insists that Bb4 or Bc5 offer better prospects.  d6 blocks the black bishop in
I get nervous leaving c4 unprotected.  For the 3rd move in a row the Games DB is heckling me to move Nf3 instead!
This is aggressive -looking but won't achieve much unsupported.  Games DB prefers Be7
I want to put some pressure on the c6 knight
This supports the knight, blocks a potential check and sets up Bh3.  So that's all good, right?

I don't see any point in Nf3 now.  I want to keep pressure on the c6 knight.  I could play Bxc6 to force bxc6 (with or without a queen exchange) and stuff his pawns up.  But I want to keep the threat alive for now.  Bg5 is also threatening to double-up his pawns
Black has little choice unless he meekly retreats back to g8.  I think Be7 would have been better.  Still, black must think that he has an attack building on the kingside
I want that bishop out of there.  h5 is now blocked and retreating to e6 will further constrict his development
An unexpected bonus because...
...that's a nasty fork!

Black appears to be able to limit the damage to 1 point here by 
9...Bxg4
10.hxg4 Qxg4
Unfortunately
11.Bxc6+ bxc6 (forced, as Kd8 is prevented and 11...Qd7 12.Bxd7#)
12.Qxc6+ Qd7 (forced)
13.Qxa8+ Qc8 (followed by 14.Qxc8#) or Qd8 (followed by Qxd8#)
[See puzzle #21064]
I considered gxf5 hoping for Qxf5 and a different version of my forced mate in 5.  However Nxg2+ would wreck that
Taking a 3-point lead
Taking a 3-point lead
